title: The Cobbler's Sacrifice
devotional:
Old Man Tiberius, as the villagers called him, wasn't known for his wealth or physical strength. He was known for his worn hands and the even more worn leather apron he always wore. Tiberius was the village cobbler. He spent his days hunched over his workbench, meticulously repairing shoes and boots. He poured his heart and soul into each stitch, each perfectly placed nail. His work wasn't just a job; it was an act of service, a way of providing for his community.

One harsh winter, a crippling sickness swept through the village. Many families were left without resources, struggling to even afford basic necessities like food and firewood. Tiberius, who himself didn't have much, knew he had to do something. He looked around his small shop, at the stacks of leather he had painstakingly saved for future repairs. He knew those materials could be sold to buy food and medicine for the sick. It was everything he had, the investment in his livelihood and future. But, he couldn't bear to see his neighbors suffer.

Without hesitation, Tiberius gathered his precious leather and went to the market in the next town. He sold it all for a fraction of what it was worth, simply wanting to get aid to those who desperately needed it. When he returned to the village, he distributed the money and supplies, bringing comfort and relief to countless families. The villagers were overwhelmed by Tiberius's generosity. They hailed him as a hero, but Tiberius simply shrugged, his worn hands already reaching for scraps of old leather, determined to find a way to continue his work, even with so little.

Tiberius' act wasn't just an act of charity; it was a sacrifice, a laying down of his own needs for the well-being of others. It reflected the ultimate sacrifice of Christ, who gave His life for the salvation of humanity.
image_description: A worn leather apron hanging on a wooden workbench in a dimly lit cobbler's shop, with various tools scattered around.
insights: Tiberius’s story echoes the biblical call to sacrifice, exemplified in Philippians 2:3-4, 'Do nothing out of selfish ambition or vain conceit. Rather, in humility value others above yourselves, not looking to your own interests but each of you to the interests of the others.' This passage underscores that true Christian living involves prioritizing the needs of others and being willing to sacrifice our own comforts and desires.
prayer: Lord, help us to see the needs of those around us and to be willing to sacrifice our own comforts and resources to meet those needs. Give us the courage to lay down our lives, in whatever small way, for the sake of others, just as Christ laid down His life for us. Amen.
reflection: What resources, talents, or possessions do you hold that you could sacrifice for the benefit of others? Are there areas in your life where you are holding on too tightly, afraid to let go for the sake of serving God and others?
